(scapes)Classifications

Gerald H. Taranto

Tue 18, January, 2022

Source: vignettes/articles/scapesClassification_01_3_classifications.Rmd
scapesClassification_01_3_classifications.Rmd

Raster classifications

scapesClassification is a package designed to perform raster classifications:

Identify discrete geographic objects and segments of space over a raster surface; each space or object is identified by a unique class or set of classes.

Design principles

The design of scapesClassification was guided by a few principles that can be resumed in the following points:

  • Raster surfaces generally present some distinctive attribute(s), easy to identify and classify;

  • Distinctive attributes can be used to map an initial set of raster cells to a class. These cells are hereafter referred to as anchor cells;

  • Then, raster cells can be classified not only considering their intrinsic attributes, but also their spatial relationships with anchor cells (see class contiguity and class continuity in rule evaluation);

  • Every time a raster portion is classified, it can be considered as a new anchor location for the following classification steps.

Classification rules

Geo-spaces are classified using sets of user-defined classification rules presented in the form of conditional statements. Classification rules evaluate either to true or false and determine, at each classification step, what raster cells are mapped to a class.

As explained in the section format inputs, (scapes)Classifications start by converting single and multi-layer raster objects into attribute tables. Each column of the attribute table represents a variable and contains the values of a raster layer. Classification rules can be built accessing by name all the variables stored in the attribute table. For instance, if our attribute table has two columns named "slope" and "height" we could build the following classification rule: "slope > 5 & height > 1000".

Rules are passed to a scapesClassification function as a single character string. They consist of combination of arithmetic (+|-|*|/|^|%%|%/%), relational (>|<|>=|<=|==|!=|%/%) and logic operators (&||), base R functions (e.g., abs(variable_name)), variables names (i.e., names(attTbl)) and previous classifications (referred to and stored as "classVector") (see ?conditions).

Types of classification rules

Absolute, test cell condition.

Absolute, test cell neighborhood condition.

Relative, focal cell condition.

Relative, test cell neighborhood condition.

Contents
